results.title: Cook's Family Farm
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Matt Blackwood, ACMI Content Development, Shelley Matulick and ACMI
results.brief_description: Meet the Cook family and spend time with three generations as they muster and milk cows. Robert and Patricia are the proud parents of five grown up sons and 22 grandchildren. Brothers, Ross and Steve Cook have returned to share-farm with their mum and dad and there is no other place they would rather be. Surrounded by rolling hills and the winery county of the King Valley in northern Victoria, the Cook family have worked hard to keep and grow their dairy farm.

results.title: The Whitlands Plateau
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Matt Blackwood, ACMI Content Development, Shelley Matulick and ACMI
results.brief_description: Distance is no barrier to this active group of entrepreneurs who have a rich history and a strong community spirit. From lawyers and artists to viticulturists and wine makers, the small plateau in Whitlands, in north-eastern Victoria, attracts a diverse group of talented and hard working professionals. We meet some life-long locals and a newcomer to town and hear about the history of the area as well as the ventures that are being undertaken in 2012 Whitlands.

results.title: The Game
results.creator_credit: Aden Porter, Joshua Ash-Miller, Laurence Gunther and Schonn-Pierre Hirst
results.brief_description:
The theme of belonging is explored by looking at rejection based on stereotypes in the schoolyard, and the effect that had on the victim. Also shown in this animated short is the impact an accepting group has on that person.

Under the category ‘Bullying. No Way! - Secondary”, Year 10, St John’s Grammar School, South Australia, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: Proud 2 Be Me!
results.creator_credit: Amy Rowe, Charlotte Kinsella, Chloe McKenna, Hannah Petrowski, Isabelle Tonna, Jessica Smith and Leah Felsbourg
results.brief_description:
A story of a little, white monster who feels like he doesn’t belong. He tries to make himself fit in, which doesn’t quite work out. The other little monsters finally decide that they like the little white monster just the way he is.

Under the category ‘Bullying. No Way! - Primary’, Years 5 and 6, St Luke’s Primary School, Victoria, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: You don't belong here [game trailer]
results.brief_description:
By staying true to your own ideals you will find a group of unique individuals where everyone belongs. A man is shipwrecked on a distant island. He must search the island for a tribe to live in by avoiding obstacles and collecting gems along the way. These tribes will take you in but on the condition you behave like them. You decline their offer saying you have a right to be yourself. You are then banished and must avoid members of these tribes as you continue your search. They attempt to catch you as you dont belong. Finally you come across a tribe that accepts you for who you are. They are all individuals and make you feel like you belong.

Under the category ‘Primary Videogames’, Liam Blake, Hope Valley, SA, was the Screen It 2012 winner.

holdings.name: MOV file H264; ACMI Digital Access Copy - presentation

results.title: Unshaded
results.brief_description:
‘Unshaded’ is a stop-motion animation made from plasticine. It explores the notion that no matter who you are, there is always a place of belonging for you. The animation is initially shot in a black and white world, reflecting the character’s thoughts of loneliness and insecurity. The character is confronted by unfamiliar creatures who seek to gain their colour back by signalling to him to tap them on the head. He does this and in return his world is restored to colour. The character realises that together they can bring happiness to each other and ultimately belong even though they may have evident differences.

Under the category ‘Secondary Animation’, Hayley Warnock, Benalla, Victoria, was the Screen It 2012 winner.

results.title: Omni
results.brief_description:
Finbar is a young man who is obsessed with pi. His fragile existence is thrown into tumult when he discovers a mysterious note in his locker…

Under the category ‘Secondary Live Action’, Blake Whelan, ACT, was the Screen It 2012 winner.

results.title: Cubbies
results.creator_credit: Darcy Drake, Kane Jutson, Max Duke and Ryan Dunt
results.brief_description:
Trust, creativity, friendship and belonging are the focus of the ‘Cubbies’ story. A group of friends use cooperation, creativity and sheer ingenuity to build 29 different ‘cubbies’. The trust given by the staff and wider school community is central.

Under the categories ‘Primary Live Action’ and ‘Best Overall Primary’, Years 5 and 6 from Doreen Primary School, Victoria, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: Mother Courage
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, video, monitor, van, mixed media props, paintings, colour and sound
results.brief_description: Mother Courage is a video and sculptural installation commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA(13). Based on Bertolt Brecht’s play ‘Mother Courage and Her Children’ the work reconstructs an immersive bushcamp environment within the gallery space, and explores the tensions between contemporary urban and traditional Indigenous lifestyles.

constellations_other.name: Warwick Thornton
constellations_other.description: Brimming with Shakespearean undertones and pathos, Kaytetye filmmaker Warwick Thornton's debut feature Samson and Delilah is both a universal tale and one intrinsically tied to the experience of First Peoples in Central Australia.

results.description:
Mother Courage is a video and sculptural installation commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA(13). Based on Bertolt Brecht’s play Mother Courage and Her Children the work reconstructs an immersive bushcamp environment within the gallery space, and explores the tensions between contemporary urban and traditional Indigenous lifestyles.

The installation comprises a white van housing a dual screen projection of an elderly Aboriginal woman artist and her grandson. Surrounded by paint pots, utensils and bedding, the woman (played by artist Grace Rubuntja) applies herself to her work, while the boy sits, bored, listening to loud Aboriginal rock music that blares out of a radio inside the van.

Mother Courage is inspired by Bertolt Brecht’s famous character Mother Courage. In Brecht’s 1939 play, Mother Courage and Her Children, the title character, displaced by war, survives by moving and adapting to whatever life throws at her. In this way, she shares common ground with many Aboriginal people, particularly those Aboriginal women who, like Mother Courage, know what it is to lose children in a hostile world.

Thornton’s Mother Courage was first exhibited in 2012 at the prestigious contemporary art exhibition dOCUMENTA (13) held in Kassel, Germany. For the period of the exhibition, it was constantly on the move, ‘parked outside the most prestigious galleries in town, for art aficionados to peer in its grimy windows through its rear doors, to wonder at the business inside’. At ACMI, the work was reborn within the space of Gallery 2, no longer on the move, but cutting against the grain of the white cube/black box experience of the art gallery space.
description_for_label:
Mother Courage is a video and sculptural installation commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA(13). Based on Bertolt Brecht’s play ‘Mother Courage and Her Children’ the work reconstructs an immersive bushcamp environment within the gallery space, and explores the tensions between contemporary urban and traditional Indigenous lifestyles.

“The installation comprises a white van housing a dual screen projection of an elderly Aboriginal woman artist and her grandson. Surrounded by paint pots, utensils and bedding, the woman (played by artist Grace Rubuntja) applies herself to her work, while the boy sits, bored, listening to loud Aboriginal rock music that blares out of a radio inside the van.
‘Mother Courage’ is inspired by Bertolt Brecht’s famous character Mother Courage. In Brecht’s 1939 play, ‘Mother Courage and her Children’, the title character, displaced by war, survives by moving and adapting to whatever life throws at her. In this way, she shares common ground with many Aboriginal people, particularly those Aboriginal women who, like Mother Courage, know what it is to lose children in a hostile world.
Thornton’s ‘Mother Courage’ was first exhibited in 2012 at the prestigious contemporary art exhibition dOCUMENTA (13) held in Kassel, Germany. For the period of the exhibition, it was constantly on the move, ‘parked outside the most prestigious galleries in town, for art aficionados to peer in its grimy windows through its rear doors, to wonder at the business inside’. At ACMI, the work was reborn within the space of Gallery 2, no longer on the move, but cutting against the grain of the white cube/black box experience of the art gallery space.” [Source: ACMI Education resource kit]
